docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT CLINTON used the word Democrat just once in his 74-minute State of the Union address last week -- exactly the same number of times he mentioned the word Republican. They were twinned in a sentence warning Saddam Hussein that the nation was united in demanding that he comply with United Nations weapons inspections. But the term bipartisan appears eight times -- a none-too-subtle signal to the public that Mr. Clinton wants to put himself above the petty party brawling that preoccupies lesser politicians.

headline.main: The Nation; Read Between the Lines for a Partisan Message

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's State of the Union Message this year used word 'bipartisan' eight times, but was nevertheless a highly partisan document that laid minefield for Republicans, and illustrated how adept Clinton has become at casting that message in nonpartisan terms that public approves; photos (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When residents of this small borough in Mercer County learned that 58 acres of gently rolling hills here and in adjacent Hopewell Township was destined for development, they took out their checkbooks. David Mackie, a 38-year-old geologist, parted with a $10,000 inheritance. Another resident, who works as an office manager, borrowed $1,000 from her life insurance policy. And Martin C. Collcutt and his wife, Akiko, extended their home equity loan by $20,000.

headline.main: In Our Backyard? No Way, They Say, Pulling Out Their Wallets

docs.abstract: Article describes work of residents in banding together to raise funds to help buy 58-acre tract to protect it from development; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is no national network for baby-sitting cooperatives. Most parents learn about them through word of mouth or through churches and synagogues or Lamaze classes. If you're thinking of forming a cooperative, keep the rules simple, experts advise. Among other things, specify where the baby-sitting will take place -- in the child's or the sitter's home; the maximum number of families allowed into the co-op (usually 10 to 20), the cost of dues (usually $8 to $40 a year, to cover items like mailings) and any penalties -- perhaps surrender of some coupons -- for not using the service often enough.

headline.main: Perhaps a Co-op Can Set You Free

docs.abstract: Article on how to organize baby-sitting cooperative (S)
